channel.title: World
channel.description: NPR world news, international art and culture, world business and financial markets, world economy, and global trends in health, science and technology. Subscribe to the World Story of the Day podcast and RSS feed.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: A Year From 'Egypt's Tiananmen,' Report Surfaces On Cairo Massacre
item.description: Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, was denied entry into Egypt last week. He had been traveling to the country to present results of a report on the 2013 massacre that left at least 817 people dead in Cairo. He spoke with NPR's Arun Rath.
item.content:encoded:
Kenneth Roth, the executive director of Human Rights Watch, was denied entry into Egypt last week. He had been traveling to the country to present results of a report on the 2013 massacre that left at least 817 people dead in Cairo. He spoke with NPR's Arun Rath.

» E-Mail This

item.title: Who's A Citizen? The Question Dividing The Island Of Hispaniola
item.description: The Dominican Republic issued a ruling last year that would render stateless many residents of Haitian origin. The government has revised its position, but the fate of many Haitians still isn't clear.
item.content:encoded:
The Dominican Republic issued a ruling last year that would render stateless many residents of Haitian origin. The government has revised its position, but the fate of many Haitians still isn't clear.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Sarah Tilotta

item.title: Thousands Of Anti-Government Protesters March In Pakistan
item.description: The demonstrators allege election fraud by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and are demanding he step down. The political instability has prompted fears of a possible army coup.
item.content:encoded:
The demonstrators allege election fraud by Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and are demanding he step down. The political instability has prompted fears of a possible army coup.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Aid Is On The Way For Eastern Ukraine, If Only It Can Pass The Checkpoints
item.description: Both Ukraine and Russia say they're trying to send supplies to residents in eastern Ukraine. But with tensions on both sides running high, that aid may take a while to arrive.
item.content:encoded:
Both Ukraine and Russia say they're trying to send supplies to residents in eastern Ukraine. But with tensions on both sides running high, that aid may take a while to arrive.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Soraya Sarhardi Nelson

item.title: Germany Eavesdropped On Kerry, Clinton, Magazine Says
item.description: Der Spiegel reports that the current and former U.S. secretary of state were the inadvertent targets of German surveillance.
item.content:encoded:
Der Spiegel reports that the current and former U.S. secretary of state were the inadvertent targets of German surveillance.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: U.S. Airstrikes In Iraq Pound Area Near Mosul Dam
item.description: The airstrikes come as at least 80 men from the religious minority were reportedly executed by militants for refusing to convert to Islam.
item.content:encoded:
The airstrikes come as at least 80 men from the religious minority were reportedly executed by militants for refusing to convert to Islam.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Russian Embargo Leaves EU Producers Holding The Apples
item.description: It's been a week since Russia implemented a ban on EU food imports. NPR's Linda Wertheimer finds out from BBC Berlin correspondent Stephen Evans what effect the sanctions are having in Europe.
item.content:encoded:
It's been a week since Russia implemented a ban on EU food imports. NPR's Linda Wertheimer finds out from BBC Berlin correspondent Stephen Evans what effect the sanctions are having in Europe.

» E-Mail This

item.title: A Sea Of Ceramic Poppies Honors Britain's WWI Dead
item.description: A hundred years after the start of World War I, 888,246 handmade red flowers are filling the moat at the Tower of London — one flower for each British or colonial life lost during the war.
item.content:encoded:
A hundred years after the start of World War I, 888,246 handmade red flowers are filling the moat at the Tower of London — one flower for each British or colonial life lost during the war.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Ari Shapiro

item.title: Ebola Quiz: How Much Do You Know About The Outbreak?
item.description: The virus has been in the headlines since March, but both in Africa and the rest of the world, there's a lot of confusion. Take our Ebola quiz to see if you've kept up with all the twists and turns.
item.content:encoded:
The virus has been in the headlines since March, but both in Africa and the rest of the world, there's a lot of confusion. Take our Ebola quiz to see if you've kept up with all the twists and turns.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: NPR Staff

item.title: Navigating Nicaragua: A Lesson In Getting Lost
item.description: If you are looking for the place where the streets have no names, then Nicaragua is it. Street names and addresses don't exist. But if you remember landmarks, you can make your way.
item.content:encoded:
If you are looking for the place where the streets have no names, then Nicaragua is it. Street names and addresses don't exist. But if you remember landmarks, you can make your way.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Even With $100 Million, WHO Says It Will Take Months To Control Ebola
item.description: The WHO has called for donations to help contain the outbreak. But money is just the first step. The challenges run from finding the right staff to prepping neighboring countries just in case.
item.content:encoded:
The WHO has called for donations to help contain the outbreak. But money is just the first step. The challenges run from finding the right staff to prepping neighboring countries just in case.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Richard Harris

item.title: Russian Military Vehicles Reportedly Move Into Ukraine
item.description: Heavy fighting continues in eastern Ukraine, as government and separatist forces still fight for control of the cities of Luhansk and Donetsk.
item.content:encoded:
Heavy fighting continues in eastern Ukraine, as government and separatist forces still fight for control of the cities of Luhansk and Donetsk.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Soraya Sarhaddi Nelson

item.title: Massive Rallies Descend On Islamabad, As Authorities Dig In Trenches
item.description: Thousands of people are converging on Pakistan's capital, Islamabad, for a protest rally against the government. The protesters began their 300-mile march in Lahore, led by Imran Khan, who believes he was robbed of last year's election by voting fraud. Meanwhile, a populist cleric is leading a separate march on the capital.
item.content:encoded:
Thousands of people are converging on Pakistan's capital, Islamabad, for a protest rally against the government. The protesters began their 300-mile march in Lahore, led by Imran Khan, who believes he was robbed of last year's election by voting fraud. Meanwhile, a populist cleric is leading a separate march on the capital.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Philip Reeves

item.title: U.S. Policy On Syria Mired In Excess Caution, Official Says
item.description: Rick Barton, a top State Department official, says sometimes the U.S. has to take risks in diplomacy. Citing his own frustrations, he says that the Obama administration has yet to come up with a real strategy to resolve the war in Syria and isolate jihadi fighters.
item.content:encoded:
Rick Barton, a top State Department official, says sometimes the U.S. has to take risks in diplomacy. Citing his own frustrations, he says that the Obama administration has yet to come up with a real strategy to resolve the war in Syria and isolate jihadi fighters.

» E-Mail This
item.dc:creator: Michele Kelemen

item.title: In Defense Of U.N. Aid In Iraq
item.description: For more on the challenges of supporting internally displaced persons in Iraq, Robert Siegel speaks with Kieran Dwyer, the spokesman for the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Dwyer responds to criticisms of the U.N. agencies trying to help.
item.content:encoded:
For more on the challenges of supporting internally displaced persons in Iraq, Robert Siegel speaks with Kieran Dwyer, the spokesman for the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. Dwyer responds to criticisms of the U.N. agencies trying to help.

» E-Mail This
